description: From Latin dēsultōrius (“hasty, casual, superficial”), from dēsultor (“a circus rider who jumped from one galloping horse to another”), from dēsiliō (“jump down”), from dē (“down”) + saliō (“jump, leap”).

adjectives.description: desultory (comparative more desultory, superlative most desultory)

entries.meaning: Jumping, or passing, from one thing or subject to another, without order, planning, or rational connection; lacking logical sequence.
examples: Synonyms: disconnected, unmethodical, aimless, quodlibetic, (in conversation) quodlibetical

entries.meaning: Out of course; by the way; not connected with the subject.
examples: I made a desultory remark while I was talking to my friend.
She made a desultory attempt at conversation.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Leaping, skipping or flitting about, generally in a random or unsteady manner.
